threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format and ideally smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking.
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the Catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads).

Do not want:
• Go to /wsr/ or /r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Want to learn more?
• The /p/ Wiki

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Crushed dreams and lost hope Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4095075

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

threads.com:
Does it makes sense to get any other camera than a Hasselblad 500 series nowadays?

I have a TLR and I was looking at Mamiyas and Bronicas for something more modern but still affordable, but at this point a lot of them are now sold close to or at Hassie prices, and in some cases more. Does it even make sense getting those anymore? Especially given that a lot of these cameras are electronic and may shit the bed any time, whereas repair shops that can service Hasselblads will probably be around for a very long time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101660
I think you misunderstood

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4090598
Of course. Cameras are just tools. Each one is different. Some more than others.

I started with Yashica TLRs. They are relatively inexpensive and have good lenses. I still use them as a backup because they are light and small. I do a lot of backpacking and enjoy the weight aspect.

I then started using a Kiev 60. The lenses are cheap and decent. The cameras are finicky and very heavy. Depending on the camera you might have to mess with it to get it running. Mine runs great now although it can be frustrating to deal with the dim focusing screen. The downside is that the lenses are limited and I really like Zeiss lenses. I am using a Pentacon 50mm and it is my favorite in the P6 lineup.

I saved up and bought a Hassy 500cm body and a Distagon 50mm. Have not received the lens yet. They are insanely expensive and I paid out the ass for an extra clean one. Nice bright screen, the sharpest lenses and lots of options. I have used one before and I instantly fell in love with it. I bought it because I like nice things and enjoying the process is 50% of the fun for me.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4090598
What do you mean "Does it make sense?"
The more expensive camera won't make your images better. For film, the body itself doesn't really matter because the image "sensor" is independent of the body. The body is just a box that holds film and mounts a lens. Do you believe that a Hasse lens is significantly better than its competitors, enough to incur such a price? Personally I don't, but that's what you're asking basically.
If you want to invest in a Hasselblad for long term usability, like 50 years down the line, sure, but right now there's little reason not to just get a Bronica S2 or SQ for 3-400$. Expensive film cameras are a meme

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
How about this as a way to get the Hasselblad or Rolleiflex look on digital?

The Zeiss Planar 50mm f1.4 will have no problems filling the frame on a Fujifilm GFX with a square crop, and has the field of view and depth of field as an 85mm f2.4.

Buying these items used shouldn't cost that much more than a Hasselblad or Rolleiflex with a Planar 80mm f2.8. It's not film so it will feel less special, but then again you won't have to pay for it, nor for processing or have to deal with scanning.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

it's poorly designed because it doesn't fit your specific wants? backblaze does what it's supposed to do: backs up your entire computer and any attached external drives. it's not a photo gallery.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
During editing I copy them from the SD card to my PC; at least they're in 2 locations at that point (although still just one physical location, which isn't great).

Once I'm finished editing, I store them locally on my Synology DS920+, and the Lightroom catalog and settings backups are there as well. The NAS syncs with backblaze and I also back it up weekly to a drive in a USB enclosure that's otherwise disconnected from the NAS and power when not backing up.

I also backup the photos to Amazon since I have prime anyway and it's unlimited including RAW files.

With this method I should be covered for local or remote disasters, as well as ransomware.

I use Flickr for my online gallery but my Pro plan renews in a few weeks and it's another big price increase this year. Sucks but that's where all my community is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: This is probably a silly question, but...does ISO performance from same size sensors change drastically? I've been looking at some 6400 ISO photos from a Fuji X-E4 and they look fine. Meanwhile anything over 2000 ISO on my canon M50 mark II looks borderline unusable. It's possible the film simulation helped mask the noise. That or the Fuji sensor is much better at handling noise.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4107852
Fuji uses X-Trans sensors which is different from standard sensors used by sony/nikon/canon etc. X-Trans 3 especially is amazing with ISO performance, to the point where i've been happy with 12800 ISO performance in colour on smaller images. X-Trans 4 on your XE-4 is also great but yeah, they will differ.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4107859
Oh, I see. The X-E4 was not mine, but I'm considering selling my canon and the 4 lenses I own to migrate to the Fuji side. The better ISO performance, the physical dials, the film simulations, the position of the viewfinder (I hate bumping my nose on the screen while using the centered viewfinder of my M50), and even the design of the camera itself (although not as important as the other factors).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4107863
play around with the settings on your canon before making the call imo because you should be able to achieve comparable results. Have you tried increasing noise reduction on your canon? I know I and a lot of other fuji users set their noise reduction to -3 and -4 (max) because of how aggressive it can be.
OFC thats not the same as using a different camera with better ISO performance but im strictly speaking as a non-gear fag. I'm drooling over the new OM-1 because of personal preference, so pick the fuji if you personally think its good, like you said film sims and ergonomics.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4107864
Yeah, I can get decent results with a fast lens (at the cost of a shallowed DoF than I sometimes would haver preferred, to keep ISO bellow 1600). I should probably stick with my M50 for at least 5 or 6 years, I know I'll lose money trying to sell it and make the switch. I wish I had researched more before before going with Canon as my first dedicated camera. At the time it seemed like the ''safe'' option.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
CCD benefits

Can anybody explain what are the benefits of CCD versus CMOS?

I heard something about the sensor's layer composition that helps getting good sharpness with old lenses, as being closer to how film performs in the focal plane rendering.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Based Panasonic is going to right the wrongs committed over the years by the camera industry with their organic sensor. A new dawn of color is coming.
https://www.43rumors.com/panasonic-again-displayed-an-organic-sensor-prototype/

last_replies.name: Art_repro_fag22
last_replies.com:
>>4099851
The only benefit of CCD based camera sensors is that they're cheap. SNR is worse, color accuracy is worse, no live view, and slower sensor read-out. There are other drawbacks that aren't due to the sensor tech, but rather due to the age of the rest of the camera. Worse burst rates, slower AF, etc.
>>4100265
CCD and CMOS due have very different spectral response without a CFA. This is why most scientific applications have CCDs. https://www.researchgate.net/figure/3-Spectral-sensitivity-graph-of-CCD-sensor-CMOS-sensor-and-human-eye-3-Width-is-5mm_fig3_216533561
>>4100533
While color accuracy has gone up with recent CFA design, its not due to less noise, its due to wider response of the filters. Though less noise is benefit of this design choice.
https://blog.kasson.com/the-last-word/optimal-cfa-spectral-response/
>>4100492
CCD's thick CFA's color response is no closer to slide film than modern CFA response. It was the camera input profiles that gave that look. Even if your goal is crazy color, its better to start with accurate color then go from there.
>>4100543
This is not true. Old MF CCDs have massive 9 micron pixels and yet still has worse SNR than any modern baby sensor. Camera processing is much harder with old CCDs due to noise and inaccurate color.
>>4103713
Filter correlation with sRGB primaries, or any other working color space doesn't tell you much about color accuracy. This is because camera sensors are linear, and working spaces have gamma. Brightness of colors relative to each(color and brightness contrast) is by far the most important aspect of color accuracy, which is initially determined by the camera input profile.
We also don't want our filters to line up with a working space in the first place, we want our camera to see colors like we do, aka the CIEXYZ color space. This is because working spaces have a defined white point, usually D50. the standard observer accounts for human color perception under any lighting conditions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4105113
>We also don't want our filters to line up with a working space in the first place, we want our camera to see colors like we do, aka the CIEXYZ color space. This is because working spaces have a defined white point, usually D50. the standard observer accounts for human color perception under any lighting conditions.
Look at the picture again. It's precisely what SMI is about. CIE-D50 is the standard they're using in that test.

last_replies.name: Art_repro_fag22
last_replies.com:
>>4105203
You and dxomark are both confused and mistaken. SMI is pretty complex measurement using the CC24 target under a well defined Standard illuminant, usually A(Tungsten) or D50. Its a measure of how close the camera filter primaries are to CIEXYZ observer primaries. If SMI is 100, a linear transformation can get you perfect color. While they do include CMI, they're all similar to each other.
>Look at the picture again. It's precisely what SMI is about. CIE-D50 is the standard they're using in that test.
If you read into the testing methodology, they test CMI, but don't use it in their score. They instead use correlation with sRGB primaries, which doesn't mean anything. CIE-D50 is a Standard illuminant, and has very little to do with CIEXYZ, which is light source independent.
SMI honestly isnt a very good color accuracy metric anyways. In color critical work, you will usually be using some kind of LUT based profile instead of matrix profile. SMI only tells us how well a camera will respond to a matrix based profile under ideal lighting conditions for a small(and not that difficult to reproduce) set of colors.

[EXIF data available. Click here to show/hide.]
Camera-Specific Properties:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106796
It has an exposure table on the back. It always fires full power. Use aperture and distance to control exposure (shutter speed does not affect electronic flash exposure, but it does vary ambient light).
Your shutter will not work with the flash (parts of image will be unexposed) at speeds faster than 1/125 seconds.
Look up or calculate guide number (number of meters* aperture @ 100 iso) and use that to calculate exposure.
a guide number of 30 in feet is a guide number of 10 in meters.

>e.g. guide number of 10, subject is 3 meters away 10/3 = 3.333, ergo use f2.8 or an intermediate stop between 2.8 and 4 if your lens has it.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Is the Cannon EOS Rebel T7 any good?
threads.com:
I have been looking at cameras online and in store this week, I've been pretty into photography this year and want to move on from just using my mobile phone.
I mostly do still life and landscape photos, typically nature and travel, with some street photography.
What are your thoughts on the Canon EOS Rebel T7? It seems pretty solid to me, and it is in my price range, but I wanted to ask some more experienced in the field whether this was good for me, or if there are any others that they would recomme

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106392
For the price of a d5300, OP could get an original Olympus E-M1. For that money you get a pro grade, metal body with excellent weather sealing and 5 axis image stabilization. Plus a a lot of other features. Then OP could pair that with the cheap, but competent Zuiko 12-50mm lens. It's not a fast lens, but it's also weather sealed, well built, can sort of do macro and has good sharpness. There's several cheap, fast primes available too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106392
>The T7 has an ancient sensor with less dynamic range than a Nikon D5100 from 2011 meaning low light will suck if you want to push shadows.
It has the 80D sensor and is fine with a 4ev push at base ISO. Which is about the same for the D5100. In low light / high ISO all cameras converge to nearly the same DR as they are bound more by the low light and less by the sensor.

In terms of high ISO noise it's a little bit behind the best sensors available today, maybe 2/3ev and probably about the same as old Nikons.

That said I do agree anon is better off with a used 80D than a new T7 because of the body ergonomics and features.

>I'd buy at minimum something like a T3i even if used. The usefulness of the articulated screen can't be understated.
The T3i has the much older 18mp sensor which does really lag behind current sensors in base ISO DR and high ISO performance.

>>4104929
Color is grey. Early morning light is usually a very soft yellow-white to blue. It's very nice. It's great for large sculpture, architecture, and car photography.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4104929
Overcast is usually too strong, it leads to monotonous light with no variations. There are exceptions, off course. Like weak overcast, or sun breaking though. When hiking hills or mountains, one will often encounter inversion, sun up top, clouds below. This gives up a proper light softbox. People often go for the obvious shots above the clouds, but it's the conditions inside the edge of the fog that can be as rewarding.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Talk about something you get autistic over in photography.
I'll start.

I've followed this advice since the start of time, if I am to shoot handheld and there's not enough light, and my camera has let's say a 50mm lens on. My lowest acceptable shutter speed should be 1/50s. In practice if I hold very very steady I can maybe go to 1/30s and still get an acceptable image.
Now. If on crop sensors, because of the crop factor, a 33mm lens is equivalent to a 50mm while letting me shoot with a 1/30s all the while getting a good image would mean technically that it is better at low light photography, excluding noise and desired photo characteristics.
But... Larger sensors have less noise, which sort of balances the need for a theoretically higher acceptable shutter speed. But to what extent?
Also, if a camera has sensor stabilization, how far can I push my acceptable shutter speed below the normal acceptable speed? 1 stop? 2 stops?
Looking at the tiny amount of data regarding this online (maybe because most photographers are not this autistic), I'm starting to think that a newer, less noisy, image stabilized APS-C camera might reign supreme in terms of low light handheld shooting.

I would add that it generally easier to manually focus with a viewfinder than a with a rear screen. This is applicable for reflex and EVF designs. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106286
>>4106290
Just because a feature isn't absolutely perfectly useful with with one specific use case you have contrived doesn't mean its 100% worthless you impulsive savage. In this instance sadly it needs to be pointed out to you that:

Zoom lenses zoom towards a center point.
The camera can be zoomed in using the rear screen to initially frame.
Then the user can switch to the the viewfinder for the shot as all they need to do is point towards the center of the area they zoomed in to.
Being able to shoot in this manner will certainly provide a steadier shooting method than just holding the camera out in front like a retard, zooming and hoping for the best keeping it steady when the shot is taken.
This method becomes indispensable when the object being photographed is moving, as aiming from directly at the eye and moving your head will always produce better results than simply holding the camera out in front at arms length and swinging it wildly.

The only beginner mistakes that could be made in this scenario are over zooming too tight so as not to have a little leeway and simply not knowing anything about the camera or where is targets. All it takes is a little practice ffs.

I guess it also needs to be pointed out to you that there are an infinite number of picture taking scenarios that can occur. Clearly an optical viewfinder will be of advantage in a good many of them. So even if not always ideal it doesn't make the feature worthless. If given the choice of a point and shoot with or without an optical viewfinder included the obvious choice for anyone serious about taking pictures will be for the one that has one regardless of how crude it is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4105818
You will be more likely to be hired as an assistant photographer if you have a full frame camera with at least 36mp, the two essential pro zooms (24-70 f2.8 and 70-200 f2.8) and a dedicated flash head. This is close to the equipment the average pro uses and can produce photos the actual photographer will be glad to include with his own work. A portrait-oriented prime lens with an aperture of f1.7 or faster and a focal length of 50 to 100mm can be a decent addition. If you can snag an A7RIII for a good price ($1k or less) I'd definitely get that.

For sports you want even more zoom but I've only ever seen job openings for assistant event photographers

You will also need a portfolio of photos of the kind of thing you are trying to get a job photographing. This proves you know how to use a camera and won't shoot an entire wedding at f2.8, 1/8s, ISO 400.

last_replies.com:

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Halloween Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4085831

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap
